title: David Sole
text:
David Michael Barclay Sole (born 8 May 1962) is a former <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> international <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player.
Rugby Union career.
Amateur career.
He was educated at <a href="Blairmore%20School">Blairmore</a> prep school and <a href="Glenalmond%20College">Glenalmond College</a>, a private school in <a href="Perthshire">Perthshire</a>.
He went to Exeter University and played for their rugby side.
He played for <a href="Bath%20Rugby">Bath</a> and then moved to play for <a href="Edinburgh%20Academical%20Football%20Club">Edinburgh Academicals</a>.
Provincial career.
He played for <a href="Scottish%20Exiles%20%28rugby%20union%29">Scottish Exiles</a> (then Anglo-Scots) in the <a href="Scottish%20Inter-District%20Championship">Scottish Inter-District Championship</a>.
When he moved to play for Edinburgh Academicals, he then turned out for <a href="Edinburgh%20District%20%28rugby%20union%29">Edinburgh District</a>.
International career.
While still with Exeter University rugby club he was capped by <a href="Scotland%20B%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland 'B'</a>. He received 5 'B' caps in total.
He made his full senior <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> debut in 1986 against France and went on to win 44 <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">caps</a> at <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%231.%20Loosehead%20prop%20.26%203.%20Tighthead%20prop">prop</a> between 1986 and 1992, with a record 25 as captain. He was also the first choice loosehead prop with the victorious <a href="British%20and%20Irish%20Lions">British Lions</a> in <a href="1989%20British%20Lions%20tour%20to%20Australia">Australia in 1989</a>.
In 1990, Sole was captain for a <a href="Grand%20Slam%20%28Rugby%20Union%29">Grand Slam</a> decider at <a href="Murrayfield%20Stadium">Murrayfield</a> against hot favourites <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a>. This is sometimes considered to be Scotland's greatest match, and one well remembered, as Richard Bath wrote:
Scotland won 13-7, denying England the Grand Slam and claiming their third Grand Slam after their previous triumphs in 1925 and 1984.
He captained a <a href="World%20XV">World XV</a> to a victory against the <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">All Blacks</a> in 1992. He made his final international appearance for Scotland in 1992 against Australia. That year he stood for election as <a href="Rector%20of%20the%20University%20of%20Dundee">Rector of the University of Dundee</a>, but despite being the favourite candidate he was defeated by <a href="Stephen%20Fry">Stephen Fry</a>.
Media career.
Since retiring Sole has worked as a co-commentator for BBC Scotland's coverage of rugby union matches.
Business career.
He has also embarked on a successful career outside of sport, becoming <a href="Managing%20Partner">Managing Partner</a> of "School for CEO'" in 2017 as well as <a href="Non-executive%20director">Non-executive director</a> of AM Bid Services.
Family.
Three of Sole's four children have also represented their country in international sport. His sons <a href="Chris%20Sole">Chris</a> and <a href="Tom%20Sole">Tom</a> both play for the <a href="Scotland%20national%20cricket%20team">Scotland cricket team</a>, while his daughter Gemma plays for the <a href="Scotland%20national%20netball%20team">Scotland netball team</a>. His other son Jamie is also a rugby player, and played professionally with <a href="Newcastle%20Falcons">Newcastle Falcons</a>.
